ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: 7. It was unfortunately clear that the professor had no interest in teaching the class.

Readings/textbooks need to be addressed. They are useful, but the coursebook written by the instructor is incomplete and would be extremely valuable if finished. Also, the chemistry book would be useful if more emphasis was put into reading it.
This is an excellent course. The science is very available to beginners, yet the depth is easily attainable for more advanced students.

Question 5: It was often difficult to get responses to questions asked via email.Question 7b: The TA was very available and helpful. However, I believe that better communication between the instructor and the TA would have significantly improved the TA's helpfulness, as he was often at a loss to explain the requirements of certain assignments.
The pace and amount of material covered -- it was a great class that I would highly recommend.
The field trips were very informative and fun. It really helped to see the concepts discussed during class "put into action."
Gabe is a great instructor.

The best part of this course was the problem sets. These really helped to reinforce the material covered in class. I also enjoyed the field trips, especially the trip to Hole in the Wall. The speaker was extremely informative and presented an interesting perspective on stormwater management technologies.
I came out of the course with a good baseline understanding of how water systems are evaluated.
Focus on application of information, such as knowing if a water quality report is "normal". Good overview of multiple facets of water quality issues.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Perhaps better coordination from the instructor - he can improve by being more available and accessible to students.
Responsiveness of primary instructor.

There is significant (over 50%) overlap in course material between this course and Physical Sciences. This course should be presented as an alternative to Physical Sciences for people with adequate background. Alternatively, this course should cover more advanced material.
Complete revision of the syllabus, starting from lecture slides to textbook to contents.

The class seemed a bit unorganized. The instructor needs to address concerns and questions in a more timely manner. Homework assignments need to be returned earlier so students may use the materials to study for exams. Connections between materials and concepts should be strengthened - there was a lot of confusion on vague questions asked on exam and homework assignments.
None that I can think of.

The overall course material was limited and rather unorganized. We had a supplementary book about the Forested Ecosystem at Hubbard Brook, but it was poorly incorporated into the class discussions. It would have been helpful if we could have gone deeper into the course content -several of the lectures were too generalized and lacked graduate-level material. The professor is very knowledgable about aquatic chemistry, but he did not do a good job sharing this knowledge with the class. He was always willing to answer questions, but I did not always know the right questions to ask to glean more information.

I felt that there was less of a focus on Pollution than I would have liked. In addition, I would have liked to have make-up classes that covered the topics that were originally supposed to be taught during the missed classes.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Instructor was never available.TA had great availability!

Gabe was exceptionally difficult to get in touch with and did not offer any regular office hours. It would also be better if the future TA held regular office hours instead of just right before exams.

The TA was very responsive and available. He responded to questions or concerns in a timely manner and also made himself available to review materials prior to exams or homework assignments.The instructor needs to make himself more available, especially with regards to questions or concerns on lecture material. The instructor made himself available after class when asked, which is great, but if a question or meeting request was sent to his email, he rarely responded. Plus, it is inconvenient that the instructor does not use his Yale email account, but rather a Gmail account. Can he not have this forwarded to gmail like the rest of us?
Excellent.
The TA was very helpful and made himself readily available to answer questions and discuss problem sets.The instructor made himself available to address questions after class.

The TA was very available, and often helpful, though, as mentioned above, he would have been more helpful had there been more communication between the instructor and the TA. The instructor was often somewhat difficult to get hold of.
Fairly good, although sometimes took a while to respond to email.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This is the only biogeochemistry class offered at FES, and its contents are not advanced enough to be graduate class.
This course is especially important to my program. It did clearly explain some difficult concepts regarding pollution in the environment.
This is an integral course for anyone interested in water quality or water resources management.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in water resource management.
I was under the impression that it would complement Organic Pollutants. It did not.
To learn more about pollutants in the environment.
I heard it was good, and it was integral to my interests.
I was very excited to take this course because it directly relates to my interests in water pollution and nutrient cycling in aquatic environments.
I wanted a general understanding of aquatic systems and how pollution is measured in them.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Above and beyond.
No, I had little expectation to begin with, but it still managed to disappoint me.

I would have liked to see more cycling of specific pollutants in the environment, but this concept may be more appropriate in another course. However, I did enjoy the material discussed and learned a lot.
Yes!

I did gain some new knowledge from this course, but overall, it failed to live up to my expectations. I felt like I already knew a lot of this material. The professor did not do a good job expanding on the basics.
Less of a focus on pollution that I would have liked.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes!
Yes - I learned a lot, but felt some material was focused on too much (e.g. Hubbard Brook), and that time could have been spent on expanding other material or reviewing some concepts.
Yes.

I gained some new knowledge about data analysis, which was helpful. However, I was hoping to go deeper into nutrient cycling and the specifics about each compound. We seemed to breeze over this material and didn't go into much detail.
I dohave a good idea of how to test for certain things in aquatic systems.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Go to every lecture and take VERY good notes! All of the material is helpful! Tests are a fair assessment of what you have learned.Excellent class!
Don't take it.Stud on your own.

The course provides valuable information, but it will require outside time to completely understand concepts. I would recommend those taking this course to stay on top of the course work, reviewing weekly to remember the vast amount of information. Also, ask questions and keep asking them if they are still not answered or clearly explained. The materials are cumulative, and it is valuable to review often and put as much emphasis on the materials from the beginning of the course as those from the end of the course.
Go over basic redox chemistry before starting the course, if possible.
This class is helpful for learning about basic data analysis, but I do not recommend it if you already have an in-depth background in chemistry and nutrient cycling.

This course gives a good, basic overview of biogeochemistry, with a strong focus on water quality. If this is what you are interested in it is a good course. However, for others it may not provide enough technical theory or engineering utility.
